thread.title: Buy of the year? Bunnies gamble paying off
thread.title_full: Buy of the year? Bunnies gamble paying off

title: Buy of the year? Bunnies gamble paying off
text:
NRL round four 2017 preview: Team news, stats and talking points — The Big Picture March 23, 2017 10:36am Source: FOX SPORTS THREE rounds in and already Luke Keary is being branded ‘buy of the year’ by sections of the rugby league community. 
But when it comes to value for money, South Sydney’s Cody Walker wins that battle by a landslide. 
In fact the only number he can’t match Keary in is the bank balance, with the Roosters’ new recruit believed to be on triple what Walker’s contract for 2017 is worth. 
The Rabbitohs backed Walker and re-signed him for far less than what the tricolours forked out for Keary. 
It means Walker is one of the lowest paid starting halves in the game, but he’s one of the best. Cody Walker of the Rabbitohs evades a tackle. Source: AAP 
According to the Fox Sports Lab , Walker is ranked second for try assists (6) this season and third in the competition for linebreaks (4) and linebreak assists (4). 
Keary is equal with Walker for linebreak assists (4) with his halves partner Mitchell Pearce claiming top spot (6). Keary’s fifth for try assists (3) and 25th for linebreaks (2). 
Without Greg Inglis for the rest of the year, Walker has become the Rabbitohs’ go-to man for X-factor. 
Ben Ikin, Nathan Ryan and Ben Glover examine Jason Taylor’s sacking at the Wests Tigers and how it impacts the club and its roster going forward. 
You can also subscribe via iTunes or for Android users, listen on the iPP Podcast Player app. 
That’s why it should come as no surprise that the No.6 has been voted players’ player in two of the club’s three games this season. 
It was only eight months ago Brisbane were eager to lure Walker north before he re-signed with Souths until the end of 2018. 
South Sydney’s backing of Walker ahead of Keary was always going to make Thursday night’s match-up one the fans had circled on the calendar. 
Thursday’s clash is Keary’s opportunity to either prove the Rabbitohs right for not re-signing him or to throw egg on their face. 
The head-to-head battle with Walker is a juicy one, even if Michael Maguire named Walker at fullback for the blockbuster. Luke Keary of the Roosters passes the ball. Source: Getty Images 
Welcome to The Big Picture - your full round four preview! 
South Sydney Rabbitohs v Sydney Roosters at ANZ Stadium, 8.05pm (AEDT) Thursday 
Rabbitohs : 1 Cody Walker 2 Alex Johnston 3 Siosifa Talakai 3 Robert Jennings 5 Bryson Goodwin 6 John Sutton 7 Adam Reynolds 8 Thomas Burgess 9 Robbie Farah 10 Jason Clark 11 Angus Crichton 12 Kyle Turner 13 Sam Burgess (c) 14 Damien Cook 15 Anthony Cherrington 16 Robbie Rochow 17 Zane Musgrove 18 David Tyrrell 19 Tyrell Tuimaono 20 Cameron Murray 21 Sitiveni Moceidreke 
Roosters : 1 Michael Gordon 2 Daniel Tupou 3 Latrell Mitchell 4 Joseph Manu 5 Shanu Kenny-Dowall 6 Luke Keary 7 Mitchell Pearce 8 Jared Waearea-Hargreaves 9 Jake Friend (c) 10 Dylan Napa 11 Boyd Cordner (c) 12 Mitchell Aubusson 13 Aidan Guerra 14 Isaac Liu 15 Zane Tetevano 16 Ryan Matterson 17 Connor Watson 18 Chris Smith 19 Paul Carter 20 Blake Ferguson 22 Mitchell Cornish 
The talking point : Luke Keary heads out west to face the club he walked away from just a few months ago. The 2014 premiership winner goes up against the Bunnies for the first time since joining the Roosters. He’s in hot form early this season and will relish the chance to get one over his former teammates. 
The odds (courtesy of UBET) : Rabbitohs $3, Roosters $1.40 
The stat : The Roosters have not won their opening four games of a season since 1996, and can break a two-decade long record if they beat the Bunnies on Thursday. Their first three wins match the start to their 2004 season. 
Our prediction : The Roosters are an unstoppable force at the moment and they’ll cruise to a fourth straight victory. 
Ben Ikin, Nathan Ryan and Ben Glover examine Jason Taylor’s sacking at the Wests Tigers and how it impacts the club and its roster going forward. 
You can also subscribe via iTunes or for Android users, listen on the iPP Podcast Player app. 
Penrith Panthers v Newcastle Knights at Pepper Stadium, 6pm (AEDT) Friday 
Panthers : 1 Matt Moylan 2 Dean Whare 3 Waqa Blake 4 Tyrone Peachey 21 Dallin Watene Zelezniak 6 Te Maire Martin 7 Nathan Cleary 8 James Tamou 9 Peter Wallace 10 Regan Campbell-Gillard 11 Bryce Cartwright 12 Isaah Yeo 13 Trent Merrin 14 Peta Hiku 15 Leilani Latu 16 Viliame Kikau 17 Sitaleki Akauola 18 Moses Leota 19 Tim Browne 20 Dylan Edwards 22 Corey Harawira 
Knights : 1 Brendan Elliot 2 Ken Sio 3 Dane Gagai 4 Peter Mata’utia 5 Nathan Ross 6 Brock Lamb 7 Trent Hodkinson 8 Daniel Saifiti 9 Danny Levi 10 Josh Starling 11 Sione Mata’utia 12 Jamie Buhrer 13 Mitchell Barnett 14 Luke Yates 15 Jack Stockwell 16 Sam Stone 17 Jacob Saifiti 18 Jacob Gagan 19 Joe Wardle 20 Josh King 21 Anthony Tupou Brendan Elliot of the Knights is treated for a head knock. Source: Getty Images 
The talking point : Newcastle already looks a far better team than the one that finished last in 2016. The Knights have beaten Gold Coast, and gone within a try of South Sydney and the Warriors. If they can spring an upset over a premiership favourite at big odds the Knights will go a long way to avoiding the dreaded wooden spoon. 
The odds (courtesy of UBET) : Panthers $1.16, Knights $5.35 
The stat : The Penrith defence needs to be switched on if they want to avoid an upset loss at the hands of Newcastle. The Panthers at home have never beaten the Knights when conceding 14 points or more (12 losses and a draw). The Panthers have their worst home record against the Knights, winning just seven of 22 games at Pepper Stadium. 
Our prediction : Penrith’s attack will tear the Knights apart. They could score upwards of 30 points quite easily. 
Brisbane Broncos v Canberra Raiders at Suncorp Stadium, 8pm (AEDT) Friday 
Broncos : 1 Darius Boyd 2 Corey Oates 3 James Roberts 4 Tautau Moga 5 Jordan Kahu 6 Anthony Milford 7 Ben Hunt 8 Korbin Sims 9 Andrew McCullough 10 Adam Blair 11 Sam Thaiday 12 Matt Gillett 13 Josh Mcguire 14 Alex Glenn 15 Tevita Pangai 16 Herman Essese 17 Jai Arrow 18 Benji Marshall 19 George Fai 20 David Mead 21 Jonus Pearson 
Raiders : 1 Jack Wighton 2 Nick Cotric 3 Jarrod Croker 4 Joseph Leilua 5 Jordan Rapana 6 Blake Austin 7 Aidan Sezer 8 Junior Paulo 9 Josh Hodgson 10 Shannon Boyd 11 Josh Papalii 12 Elliot Whitehead 13 Luke Bateman 14 Adam Clydsdale 15 Iosia Soliola 16 Clay Priest 17 Dave Taylor 18 Jordan Turner 19 Scott Sorensen 20 Dunamis Lui 22 Joseph Tapine Anthony Milford at Broncos training. Source: News Corp Australia 
The talking point : Anthony Milford is about to sign a lucrative contract extension with Brisbane according to reports, and it’s ironic the news comes in the same week he goes up against the club that let him walk away. Milford could have been in the lime green had the Broncos not poached him from the Raiders a couple of years back. Will he burn the old team? 
The odds (courtesy of UBET) : Broncos $1.65, Raiders $2.25 
The stat : If Brisbane reaches 22 points on the scoreboard, they just win. The Broncos have won every game against the Raiders at Suncorp when scoring 22 or more. On the slip side, the Broncos have lost four from four when scoring 16 points or less. 
Our prediction : Broncos will sneak home in a tight one, and Milford will have a night out. 
Manly Sea Eagles v Canterbury Bulldogs at Lottoland, 4.30pm (AEDT) Saturday Morris wary of Tommy Turbo 0:36 
Sea Eagles : 1 Tom Trbojevic 2 Jorge Taufua 3 Dylan Walker 4 Brian Kelly 5 Akuila Uate 6 Blake Green 7 Daly Cherry-Evans (c) 8 Brenton Lawrence 9 Api Koroisau 10 Martin Taupau 11 Frank Winterstein 12 Curtis Sironen 13 Jake Trbojevic 14 Lewis Brown 15 Nate Myles 16 Jackson Hastings 17 Addin Fonua-Blake 18 Shaun Lane 19 Jarrad Kennedy 20 Matthew Wright 21 Billy Bainbridge 
Bulldogs : 1 Brad Abbey 2 Brett Morris 3 Josh Morris 4 Brenko Lee 5 Marcelo Montoya 6 Josh Reynolds 7 Moses Mbye 8 Aiden Tolman 9 Michael Lichaa 10 James Graham 11 Josh Jackson 12 Greg Eastwood 13 David Klemmer 14 Sam Kasiano 15 Danny Fualalo 16 Adam Elliot 17 Raymond Faitala-Mariner 18 Craig Garvey 19 Matt Frawley 20 Francis Tualau 21 Reimis Smith 
The talking point : A scrappy win over the Warriors last week won’t do much to silence the noise surrounding Des Hasler and his position as Bulldogs coach. The idea has been floated he’ll return to Manly at the end of the year, replacing Trent Barrett. But Barrett masterminded a huge upset over the Cowboys last week and his job, at least for the time being, seems a little more secure. 
The odds (courtesy of UBET) : Sea Eagles $1.91, Bulldogs $1.91 
The stat : History says this game will be tight. The Bulldogs have won nine of the past 11 games against Manly, but seven of the games have been decided by single figure margins. And three have gone to golden point, of which the Dogs have won all three. 
Our prediction : It could go to extra time again, but this time we’re backing the Sea Eagles to scrape across the line. 
Parramatta Eels v Cronulla Sharks at ANZ Stadium, 7pm (AEDT) Saturday 
Eels : 1 Bevan French 2 Semi Radradra 3 Michael Jennings 4 Brad Takairangi 5 Josh Hoffman 6 Clint Gutherson 7 Corey Norman 8 Suaia Matagi 9 Kaysa Pritchard 10 Tim Mannah 11 Manu Ma’u 12 Frank Pritchard 13 Beau Scott 14 Nathan Brown 15 Daniel Alvaro 16 David Gower 17 Siosaia Vave 18 Rory O’Brien 19 Cameron King 20 Kirisome Auva’a 21 Jeff Robson 
Sharks : 1 Jack Bird 2 Sosaia Feki 3 Kurt Capewell 4 Ricky Leutele 5 Valentine Holmes 6 James Maloney 7 Chad Townsend 8 Andrew Fifita 9 Jayden Brailey 10 Matt Prior 11 Luke Lewis 12 Wade Graham 13 Paul Gallen 14 Jayson Bukuya 15 Chris Heighington 16 Jeremy Latimore 17 Joseph Paulo 18 Tony Williams 19 Gerard Beale 20 James Segeyaro 21 Edrick Lee Valentine Holmes of the Sharks is tackled. Source: Getty Images 
The talking point : Two of the game’s hottest young fullbacks go head to head in what could prove an electric match-up. If Val Holmes goes to fullback and Jack Bird moves to the outside backs for Cronulla, Holmes will be squaring off with Eels young gun Bevan French. 
The odds (courtesy of UBET) : Eels $1.91, Sharks $1.91 
The stat : Expect a big, big score. The winning team in the past five games between the Eels and Sharks has scored at least 32 points. Three of the past five have been decided by a margin of 18 points or more. 
Our prediction : Sharks will get home a tight one and it will be Val Holmes who lights up ANZ. 
Gold Coast Titans v North Queensland Cowboys at Cbus Super Stadium, 9pm (AEDT) Saturday 
Titans : 1 Tyler Cornish 2 Tyrone Roberts-Davis 3 Dale Copley 4 Konrad Hurrell 5 Daniel Vidot 6 Kane Elgey 7 Ashley Taylor 8 Jarrod Wallace 9 Tyrone Roberts 10 Ryan James 11 Kevin Proctor 12 Chris McQueen 13 Agnatius Paasi 14 Ryan Simpkins 15 Nathaniel Peteru 16 Leivaha Pulu 17 Joe Greenwood 18 Max King 19 Karl Lawton 20 Paterika Vaivai 21 Morgan Boyle 
Cowboys : 1 Kalyn Ponga 2 Kyle Feldt 3 Javid Bowen 4 Kane Linnett 5 Gideon Gela-Mosby 6 Michael Morgan 7 Johnathan Thurston 8 Patrick Kaufusi 9 Jake Granville 10 Scott Bolton 11 Gavin Cooper 12 Coen Hess 13 Ethan Lowe 14 Ben Hampton 15 John Asiata 16 Shaun Fensom 17 Sam Hoare 18 Corey Jensen 19 Ben Spina 20 Enari Tuala 21 Braeden Uele Tyler Cornish of the Gold Coast Titans is tackled. Source: AAP 
The talking point : The little brother of Queensland rugby league has the chance to stamp its authority with a big upset away from home. The Cowboys came unstuck last week against Manly while the Titans scored a good win against Parramatta, and the visitors will be boosted with a couple of backline additions. 
The odds (courtesy of UBET) : Titans $2.25, Cowboys $1.65 
The stat : The magic number for North Queensland is 22. The Cowboys have beaten the Titans all nine times they’ve scored 22 or more points in a game. 
Our prediction : Johnathan Thurston and his Cowboys will bounce back from a horror loss last week and could put a score on the Titans. 
Wests Tigers v Melbourne Storm at Leichhardt Oval, 4pm (AEDT) Sunday 
Tigers : 1 James Tedesco 2 David Nofoaluma 3 Kevin Naiqama 4 Michael Chee Kam 5 Moses Suli 6 Mitchell Moses 7 Luke Brooks 8 Aaron Woods (c) 9 Matt McIlwrick 10 Ava Seumanufagai 11 Sauaso Sue 12 Chris Lawrence 13 Elijah Taylor 14 Tim Grant 15 Josh Aloiai 16 Joel Edwards 17 Matt Ballin 18 Justin Hunt 19 Kyle Lovett 20 Jamal Idris 21 Junior Tatola 
Storm : 1. Billy Slater 2. Young Tonumaipea 3. William Chambers 4. Cheyse Blair 5. Josh Addo-Carr 6. Ryley Jacks 7. Cooper Cronk 8. Jesse Bromwich 9. Cameron Smith 10. Jordan McLean 11. Felise Kaufusi 12. Kenneath Bromwich 13. Dale Finucane 14. Christian Welch 15. Tim Glasby 16. Nelson Asofa-Solomona 17. Vincent Leuluai 18. Mark Nicholls 19. Joe Stimson 20. Justin Olam 21. Brodie Croft Munster suffers broken jaw 1:03 
The talking point : Andrew Webster, come on down! A fourth head coach takes charge of the Tigers in the space of seven years, but will their fortunes change? They’ve been belted two weeks in a row and now take on the might of Melbourne in front of a home crowd entitled to feel a little flat. Who knows what will happen. 
The odds (courtesy of UBET) : Tigers $2.70, Storm $1.47 
The stat : Since 2013 just one of six coaches has won their first game when taking the reins mid-season. That was James Shepherd who took over from interim Sharks coach Peter Sharp in 2014. Andrew Webster has to break the cycle. 
Our prediction : This game produced a thriller last year but the Tigers will be hard pressed to score a try against the Storm going off the past fortnight. 
St George Illawarra Dragons v Warriors at UOW Jubilee Oval, 6.30pm (AEDT) Sunday 
Dragons : 1 Josh Dugan 2 Nene Macdonald 3 Euan Aitken 4 Tim Lafai 5 Jason Nightingale 6 Gareth Widdop (c) 7 Josh McCrone 8 Russell Packer 9 Cameron McInnes 10 Paul Vaughan 11 Tyson Frizell 12 Joel Thompson 13 Jack de Belin 14 Tariq Sims 15 Leeson Ah Mau 16 Jacob Host 17 Kurt Mann 18 Jai Field 19 Taane Milne 20 Luciano Leilua 21 Hame Sele 
Warriors : 1 Roger Tuivasa-Sheck, 2 Tuimoala Lolohea, 3 David Fusitu’a, 4 Solomone Kata, 5 Ken Maumalo, 6 Mafoa’aeata Hingano, 7 Shaun Johnson, 8 Albert Vete, 9 Issac Luke, 10 Jacob Lillyman, 11 Bodene Thompson, 12 Ryan Hoffman, 13 Simon Mannering. Interchange: 14 Erin Clark, 15 Charlie Gubb, 16 Sam Lisone, 17 Bunty Afoa, 18 James Gavet, 20 Ligi Sao, 21 Blake Ayshford, 22 Kieran Foran Kieran Foran (L) and Shaun Johnson look on. Source: Getty Images 
The talking point : Will he or won’t he? Kieran Foran is named on an extended bench but it remains to be seen whether he’ll actually make the final 17 or not. And if he does, it will be interesting to see if he starts on the bench, and what role he plays once he comes on. His return spells bad news for young Ata Hingano. 
The odds (courtesy of UBET) : Dragons $1.85, Warriors $1.95 
The stat : The Dragons have dominated the Warriors over the years. They’ve won 19 of 24 clashes, 11 of the past 12, and have won 11 of 12 overall when playing in NSW. The Warriors are up against it. 
Our prediction : The Warriors are the Warriors, so good luck tipping this game. But we’ll take the Dragons by a couple of tries. 
Live stream the round four NRL action on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW ! View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
